claim: It's always humid in Hong Kong.

supporting.text: Hong Kong has a humid subtropical climate, characterized by high humidity levels for most of the year.

attacks.text: Hong Kong has a humid subtropical climate, characterized by high humidity levels for most of the year.
During winter months (December to February), Hong Kong experiences lower humidity due to the influence of the northeast monsoon.
Even in winter, relative humidity in Hong Kong rarely drops below 60%, which is still considered humid by many standards.
Urban areas in Hong Kong often experience lower humidity than rural areas due to the urban heat island effect.
The urban heat island effect primarily affects temperature, not humidity, and Hong Kong's coastal location maintains high humidity throughout the city.

supporting.text: During the summer months, Hong Kong experiences very high humidity due to its coastal location and monsoon influence.

attacks.text: During the summer months, Hong Kong experiences very high humidity due to its coastal location and monsoon influence.
In winter, Hong Kong's humidity drops significantly due to the influence of dry northerly winds from mainland China.
Even in winter, Hong Kong's proximity to the sea ensures that humidity levels remain relatively high compared to inland areas.
Hong Kong's urban heat island effect can sometimes reduce perceived humidity despite high actual humidity levels.

supporting.text: Winter months in Hong Kong can be less humid, with relative humidity dropping significantly compared to other seasons.

attacks.text: Winter months in Hong Kong can be less humid, with relative humidity dropping significantly compared to other seasons.
Even in winter, Hong Kong's relative humidity often remains above 60%, which is still considered humid by many standards.
60% relative humidity is not universally considered humid; many regions experience much higher levels, making Hong Kong's winter humidity relatively mild.
The claim refers to general perception, and Hong Kong is widely known for its humid climate year-round, even if winter is less humid than summer.
General perception is subjective and varies among individuals; some may not find Hong Kong's winter humidity notable.

supporting.text: The annual average relative humidity in Hong Kong is around 77-78%, indicating generally high but not constant humidity.

attacks.text: The annual average relative humidity in Hong Kong is around 77-78%, indicating generally high but not constant humidity.
While the average is high, humidity levels frequently exceed 90% during summer months, making it feel consistently humid for extended periods.
Even during high-humidity months, dry spells and seasonal variations can bring humidity below 60%, contradicting the 'always humid' claim.
Hong Kong's coastal location and monsoon climate create persistent humidity, with rare exceptions not negating the general perception of constant humidity.
Urban heat island effects in Hong Kong further amplify humidity perception, making it feel perpetually humid despite minor statistical fluctuations.

supporting.text: Cold, dry air from the north during winter can reduce humidity levels in Hong Kong temporarily.

attacks.text: Cold, dry air from the north during winter can reduce humidity levels in Hong Kong temporarily.
Hong Kong's proximity to the ocean ensures high humidity levels persist even during winter.
Historical weather data shows that relative humidity in Hong Kong rarely drops below 70%, even in winter.
Cold, dry air masses from the north are often modified by the South China Sea before reaching Hong Kong, reducing their drying effect.

supporting.text: Hong Kong's urban heat island effect can contribute to higher humidity levels in built-up areas compared to rural areas.

attacks.text: Hong Kong's urban heat island effect can contribute to higher humidity levels in built-up areas compared to rural areas.
Hong Kong's coastal location and monsoon climate ensure high humidity across all regions, not just urban areas.
Rural areas in Hong Kong, such as the New Territories, can experience lower humidity due to vegetation and less concrete.
The urban heat island effect is not the primary driver of humidity; seasonal weather patterns dominate.
Urban areas trap moisture from human activities (e.g., air conditioning exhaust), amplifying localized humidity.
